result.taxonomicnotes: This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List as Pseudotropheus cyaneus Stauffer, 1988 but is now valid in the genus Chindongo Li, Konings & Stauffer, 2016.
result.rationale: This species is endemic to Lake Malawi where it is only known from a single island. It meets the area requirements under criterion B for Critically Endangered and it is known from one location. However, future declines in habitat quality or population size are possible but uncertain. The effects of sedimentation on this species are unknown and it is, therefore, listed as Near Threatened.
result.geographicrange: This species is endemic to Lake Malawi where it is only known from Chinyamwezi Island.
result.population: No information is available on the population.
result.habitat: This species occurs in rocky habitat (frequently near small rocks) at depths to about 40 m. Territorial males are seen all year round, and their territory consists of a cave among the rocks. This species feeds on algae from rock surfaces, as well as on plankton in the water column. The maximum size is 9 cm total length.
result.threats: Sedimentation is the primary threat to this species.
result.conservationmeasures: The entire distribution of this species is within the Lake Malawi National Park.
result.usetrade: This species is not targeted by the ornamental fish trade.
